Why am I being given a bonifre to check for palindromes when I still dont even have a full grasp of the basics yet? Its not fair to us who are trying to learn this programming language for the first time because we have no idea what to do and then we get discouraged and it makes us feel like we can't do it because we dont even have the basics down yet. I think FCC should let campers practice more to get the basics down and embedded into our heads before making us move onto a bonfire of some truly advanced stuff that makes no sense to us at all.

@evaristoc I went into the FreeCodeCamp/Help room once and never got any help or acknowledgement for that matter. That's why I went into other rooms and finally got some assistance.

Yes, @mildused : this is something that is not going to change: most of the users are new to the tool and the rules are soft... when people are desperate for a solution, they will try different channels... then there will always be someone who will try to help instead of asking to use a "regular channel"...

It seems wrong, but it is not totally so: actually I would think about training people in the use of few existing Gitter features before asking for help or even before trying the camperbot to solve a problem... The information has been there, it always was...

I have studied innovation management in the past and one of the first thing I learned was: new solutions will come with new problems... Sometimes it is rather about cultural change than technological change, and finding the balance... imo

@evaristoc I agree about your room theory. There are many rooms that fill the same purpose. For example, people ask for help in the /CodeReview room and the /Help room. They are very interchangeable and it causes a lot of clutter. There are other examples, but that's the one I can think of right now.

People: I don't know how to put this one... I know that the disaggregation is thought as a better way to help, but I have the impression is overused:
* I am not sure if creating MORE sub-rooms for every specific problem would be a good idea... There are a few things that we should consider, particularly the possibility of having NUMEROUS rooms to visit in order to find a solution
* The Gitter's Search has been substantially **underused**: before I used it to find solutions to problems, it was the richest way to see how others did it
* Probably one of the most important countereffects: before one or several helpers were dealing with one or more problems in a centralised channel, creating a outstanding knowledge base; now the helpers have to visit not just one but about **100 rooms!!!** in order to provide assistance.

I am trying to think on this in terms of **knowledge management** techniques, and I am not sure if a so detailed "divide and conquer" strategy is well applicable here: in my opinion, a centralized data source was working the best....

A topic channel is advisable when the activity should be kept as an specific one and sharing the info would actually create noise to those who might not be interested, but in the case of bonfires there are more advantages to get everyone together than in separate rooms. I agree though that creating bonfires, ziplines or basejumps as separate, as well as *additional info* rooms like comparing codes are a good level of desaggregation. 

What I also like is the idea of the wiki. Other thing is that the bot is overtaking (without purpose) the whole Search: before I could find solutions to problems with the Search feature, now it is only the bot and no solutions... that knowledge base is now invisible to us... but this is likely something that can be corrected with canalising the knowledge database into the wiki...
There is a small project that would start soon about the topic. There is a discussion going on at **/DataScience channel**

Would you want to sign an NDA for a free service? Even if it were a learning experience?
So if a non-profit wants an NDA signed that extends past the end of the project, what happens then?
No, you got it.
Does that make sense @piecedigital, or am I missing something about your concern?
Without a contract, there’s nothing they can do to stop you from doing so. And even an employer can’t stop you unless you’ve signed an NDA or other contract that stipulates that you can’t.
They can keep the repo private, but you can still show the code to a future employer or client.
Ok, I can understand that. But what if they decide that they want to keep it private?

Think of it from the side of the nonprofits, there’s a chance a nonprofit may want a private repo simply because they don’t want their name on a project until they have been reassured through a final project that an inexperienced camper team is able to ship.
Like I said before, just because it is private doesn’t mean you can’t show a potential employer the code.
So what could is a project if the repo is private?
My opinion is that even if some campers project comes across unexpected challenges or turns sour, this is still valid experience that can be spun in a job interview.

That’s how I see it. I’m going to get off the soapbox now, but this is not a business with international law specializing attorneys. It’s a place for people to code for a cause. The rest of that crap is just that
I am not your agent. I see this as a project to unite two interested parties, and do what I can to help a code newbie build something useful that will be used.

so I guess what I’m asking you, is how many more barriers do you want to put between an eager coder looking for a free project idea, and a needy nonprofit willing to give them a chance with virtually no programming experience?
Then we have a 5 way meeting to discuss the scope of the project and introduce everyone
The ones that pass that measure I then call on the phone, to make sure they’re serious and communicate well. Then they have to sign this pledge: http://goo.gl/forms/YziLgljjKG
@piecedigital We turn down probably half the proposals
We also need to accept the fact that we'll have to say no to some people, even if it's a rare occurrence, due to not falling within the guidelines that we create.
I don't know. I'll have to think about it, maybe research some things. I don't want it to be over complicated for anyone but we still need to be safe.
What do you have in mind?

Getting work without cost often opens the door to ungrateful behavior, lack of respect, inconsideration, and unmeasured worth. And no one is an exception. That's where I worry.
What I'd like to see is a safe guard for our campers so that they don't have to worry about their working  not benefiting them as it is meant to.
We dont assign projects. We tap interested parties and allow them access to an organization who needs their help
But nobody is forcing anyone to work on anything for FCC

And one last quote from the intro and I’m done:
> An alternative functional style of programming is
founded on the use of combining forms for creating
programs. Functional programs deal with structured
data, are often nonrepetitive and nonrecursive, are hierarchically
constructed, do not name their arguments, and
do not require the complex machinery of procedure
declarations to become generally applicable. Combining
forms can use high level programs to build still higher
level ones in a style not possible in conventional languages.

> Conventional programming languages are growing
ever more enormous, but not stronger. Inherent defects
at the most basic level cause them to be both fat and
weak: their primitive word-at-a-time style of programming
inherited from their common ancestor--the von
Neumann computer, their close coupling of semantics to
state transitions, their division of programming into a
world of expressions and a world of statements, their
inability to effectively use powerful combining forms for
building new programs from existing ones, and their lack
of useful mathematical properties for reasoning about
programs.

@Rybar I would dissuade campers from writing a ton of custom CSS for the same reason I’d dissuade them from trying to deploy on AWS instead of just using Heroku - they can manage without, and time is limited.

@Rybar I often hear the accsibility of each tool described as so: Bootstrap is for backend/full stack developers, Foundation for front end developers, and other CSS frameworks or custom CSS is for web designers. Though I think it’s great that people are deep enough in CSS that they’re comfortable venturing out and building their own responsive frameworks, I don’t see FCC’s site itself leaving Bootstrap any time soon. The main reason for this is we want to use the same tools that we teach. And because there’s so much else to learn, I don’t think we’ll have time to teach much beyond raw CSS and Bootstrap (though we might be able to squeeze in some LESS).

@QuincyLarson I would argue that jQuery and underscore solve more fundamental problems than bootstrap does, that's not an equivalent argument. The author addresses the time freed argument in his article, giving alternatives that are more modular/granular in nature, and not the all or nothing solution that bootstrap tends to be.  Bootstrap crosses over into visual design territory and it's complexity discourages customizing its component parts, the end result being pre-defining what your site should look like without some serious customization, which I don't agree with at all.  The argument that it makes many websites look same-y and cookie cutter-ish is valid.

@phlacin also, regarding weeding out…my personal opinion is that we should do absolutely everything we can through training, challenges, and chatroom support so that no one need be weeded out unless they give up themselves. But at the same time, I think sometimes the best thing to offer at certain stages of learning is some “tough love,” where users are forced to get outside of their comfort zones and feel completely lost for a moment. If anyone ever feels like that and can’t unstick themselves, they can always come to the chatroom or forum and find clarity. The bonfire challenges seem like the best place to get lost in the darkness of confusion because they are meant to be done in pairs. Two people lost is far less lonely than one. If people choose to do the bonfires without pairing, then they are missing out on that important aspect. If they give up because they didn’t pair, then there isn’t much we can do for them because they didn’t follow the guidelines laid out to help them learn.

The “C” is at 6 letters down, 2 letters over.

Then your job is to return a 2d array with the coordinates from the grid. Like this for CODE in the above example:
```
[[6, 2], [5, 3], [4, 4], [3, 5]]
```
My point is, you just can't expect new coders to know "how" to attack a problem if it's a new concept to them.

@phlacin regarding that challenge, it makes more sense if you see it in context of the tests. You write a function that takes a string as the first argument like this:
```
'F S E K F L S K\\nE Y Y C S E D L\\nB N X M E A D A\\nF E N D L S E D\\nQ N O K E L S D\\nJ C W E N L I O\\nP Q C N L C W L’
```

And take a word as the second argument like `CODE`
But there's tons of hand holding in pair programming when you've got two people of unbalanced skill levels. It's part of the learning process, I feel.
but I think we can address that by emphasizing everything outlined above. That there’s no hand holding on a real project, we’ve shown you the RSAP method etc
We might be criticized for not preparing campers for the challenges
So, here's my problem @brndnb, I'm having trouble even figuring out where to even begin with that kind of challenge. Am I supposed be figuring out how to "hide" the second argument?

**Maybe instead of creating a bunch of challenges and trying to categorize them afterward, we could start with a master list of concepts that build upon each other that we could then translate into actual challenge problems?**

For me the above challenge incorporates the need to translate what humans see into what computers understand. Those strings of characters and line breaks do not “hide” words to a computer. But we can translate it into a visual that humans can search for this word. So then the challenge requires the user to think differently about the problem because you can’t just tell the computer to go find the word the same way that a human would.

The only challenge I have come across is how to simplify something real-ish world into something bite-size. For example, I believe this following challenge provides some real world parsing challenge, but is it still too complex for a bite-size challenge?
> "Write a function that accepts a randomized 8 x 7 capital letter grid in the form of a string with line breaks and one space between each letter column as the first argument and a 3 to 7 letter string as the second argument. The second argument is hidden in horizontal, vertical, or diagonal view somewhere within the grid. Your job is to return the coordinates (Row, Column) of the second argument in an array.”

```
Example grid “visual”
Find the string "CODE" in the grid below.

F S E K F L S K
E Y Y C S E D L
B N X M E A D A
F E N D L S E D
Q N O K E L S D
J C W E N L I O
P Q C N L C W L
```
Or even if they are contrived and not so real world, they can apply a real world concept to them.

Yes @Rybar the way that I have been framing my approach to writing challenges is to stay as far away from math puzzles as possible. Someone learning to code shouldn’t necessarily need to have a strong background in math. Like you said, more real-world problems stripped down to simple bite-size problems would be very useful.

^ Yes @ this.   Less hand-holding.  What I'd like to see with some bonfire challenges (I may try my hand at making some myself) is more challenges that present a stripped-down version or portions of coding problems you'll run into regularly in production.  How to string encode the look-say sequence is a fun mathematical diversion, but of little practical use.
So @QuincyLarson @terakilobyte any thoughts on burning down the user facing flame levels?

I think we feel the easy ones are "harder" than the intermediate because once we know "how" a part of the puzzle can be solved, that part isn't hard anymore. Thus the "hard" part of the easy challenges is just the sheer fact that being new to coding means you're not going to know "how" to solve something or to know which method is the correct one

Yes, that’s what I think the important part of Code challenges are. Instead of providing a lot of context and hand-holding like code academy or codeschool, the code puzzle challenges stretch the “wtf? where do I start” muscles.
Truth be told, the "hardest" part of any of the CoderByte challenges is just knowing where to even begin to solve the problem

That’s one of the complaints on coderbyte. Some easy challenges take way longer than medium challenges to complete, so they appear to be categorized poorly. But if there are not categories, that isn’t a complaint someone can have. And then on the backend, we would continue to tweak the challenge order based on tracking and feedback.

I mean, I guess with Code School and Codecademy, I just assume that the challenges build on top of each other and it's implied that as I advance in the course, things won't be "harder," just new to me.

Actually, now that you’re making me think about this, if we got rid of the user facing challenge levels, then the user experience is more of one where they are presented challenges as a path to learning. Some challenges will be more challenging than others depending on what parts of javascript the user is most comfortable with. But without demarkations, they will be far less frustrated by one challenge being “easy” in their mind and the next one being “hard” only to have the next one be “easy” again.
But if you don’t see a level demarkation on the palindrome, then you’re not preoccupied with the idea of later challenges? I guess in some ways that makes sense.

That is a very good point. I think we should consider removing them unless someone has a better reason. I know originally, the idea of levels were going to be depicted by substances with higher and higher levels of combustibility.
Like I said, if knowing the palindrome was an "easy" 1 flame, it really makes me nervous about the 3 flame puzzles

As a user, I don't really think I benefit from knowing that I'm on a 1 flame puzzle. I should be able to put my trust in the challenge creators that if the puzzles are early on, it should be somewhat easier for me to resolve.
At least in my mind, it really shouldn’t matter how many attempts or how long it took to solve, as long as they plow through it, the end goal of pushing themselves and learning is most important.
I think that could be very discouraging to new coders.
No! I definitely don’t think we want that.
Unless there's a metric that says "85.443% of users got this correct on the first submission"
Convention?
Good question. We need it on the backend so that we’re not presenting the user with a extremely challenging puzzle for their first challenge, but why does the user need it?
So, then I'll ask this...why do we even need the "level of difficulty" meter for the user?
The question is, after 100 hours of coursework, will they be stable enough to approach the 900 hours of nonprofit work, or will they be still be constantly desiring their hints?
Those two places give hints if needed. We should obviously discourage the use of the hints unless they are ABSOLUTELY needed, but encourage the user to do what they can to not have to use the hints

And in that same vein, it is also what makes them weak in the long-run; they don’t provide enough for long-term success. Someone has to eventually break away from the hand-held challenges and start writing their own stuff.
I think that's one of the things that makes Codecademy and Code School so appealing. They're geared towards that person who doesn't know why they need to struggle yet.

You do bring up a good point, any challenge website can seem far more daunting than it really needs to be because for most new coders that have been reading books or following online courses, challenges are the first time they have to swim in the deep end alone without any support.
That seems fair.

> Diff Two Arrays: Compare two arrays and return a new array with any items not found in both of the original arrays.

Here is my rough draft thoughts on difficulty:
* **Level 1** Easy; can be solved with minimal lines of code and under 10 minutes
* **Level 2** Medium; puzzles that may take time to think of a solution, but aren’t actually very challenging to code.
* **Level 3** Hard; expect to spend some time on these challenges.
* **Level 4** For serious; Real-world snippets that will probably require more elaborate code.
* **Level 5** Mind-Melting; These could be one liner solutions or 100s of lines of code, the only thing these challenges have in common is that the average user will be beating their head in frustration at least once or twice.

We could also simply A/B test it. Some users get the added details button, and some don’t. On average, are users with or without the buttons completing tests faster. Not that speed is the goal, but if we found a large difference between details vs no details, it could provide some insight into whether the details clarify or waste time.

Without the option of a detailed description, we won’t have much to judge the clarity of a challenge’s concise description besides amount of time on a page or amount of test runs. But those markers don’t really differentiate between a challenge being complex and a challenge description being incomprehensible.

With this new idea of concise/detailed description of the problem, we could gather a lot more data. When someone enters a challenge, what do they do first? What percentage of users are immediatley clicking to run the test cases, which percentage of users are immediately clicking the details button. With that extra data, we could better assess if the detailed button is helping, or if most are ignoring it. Or, for challenges that receive a larger proportion of detail button clicks, we may need to assess whether that challenge question is clear or if it can be improved.

As long as all necessary info is provided in the brief description, I could see that working. A user shouldn't be required to open the details section to solve the problem. It is simply provided to help people that either need more context or get stuck. Sort of like a hint/detail button.

Ok. What about this for a rough draft description?
```
You have been put in charge of a campground website's signup form. Specifically, you have been asked to validate US phone numbers before forms are submitted. 

Be forwarned, the camp leader is easy to upset, so don't try to pull anything like requiring the user to enter a phone number in a specific format.

The user can fill out the form field any way that they choose as long as it is a valid US number. The following are all valid formatting for US numbers:

555-555-5555
(555)555-5555
(555) 555-5555
555 555 5555
5555555555
1 555 555 5555

For this challenge you will be presented with a string. Your job is to validate or reject the US phone number. Expected result is true or false.
```
From that you can create a few public tests to reinforce the description

here's what I came up for a sample format I expect challenges to conform to
```
{
  title: 'An example challenge for Bonfire',
  difficulty: 1, // should be a range from 1-5
  description: 'Your job is to determine if a provided string is a palindrome. The definition of a palindrome can be found at ' +
              'http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Palindrome . Strings will be passed in  with varying formats, such as "racecar", ' +
              '"RaceCar", and "race CAR" among others. Return true if the string is a palindrome, otherwise false',
  publicTests:['expect(palindrome("eye")).to.be.a.("boolean");', 'assert.deepEqual(palindrome("eye"), true);',
                'assert.deepEqual(palindrome("race car"), true);', 'assert.deepEqual(palindrome("not a palindrome"), false);'],
  privateTests: ['assert.deepEqual(palindrome("A man, a plan, a canal. Panama"), true);',
                'assert.deepEqual(palindrome("never odd or even"), true);', 'assert.deepEqual(palindrome("nope"), false';],
  challengeSeed: 'function palindrome(str) {\n' +
                 '  // Good luck!\n' +
                 '  return true;\n' +
                 '}\n\n'
}
```

Hi everyone, I’m thrilled to announce we have two new Camp Counselors! 

Ellie is a designer in Seattle who’s making fast progress through our challenges. She’ll be helping out with some of our design tasks. Her design portfolio (and photography!) are located here: http://ellieadamsdesign.com/

James is a mathematician and experienced developer from Minneapolis. He’s already completed all of our challenges and contributed to Free Code Camp’s code base! He’ll participate in our nonprofit projects while continuing to improve Free Code Camp and Bonfire.

On a personal note, I've been looking for a way to contribute to FCC that feels meaningful to me. Yes, I know that greeting folks in chat is IMPORTANT and I do that as much as i can, but for me, that is not personally meaningful. And my coding skills are not good enough to meaningfully contribute to the awesome updates that are happening here. And we already have someone who's awesome at dealing with the non-profit side. So, this is an excellent chance for me to contribute. :-)

Regarding helping campers get jobs, I know that for-profit-brick-and-mortar boot camps do this - actively help their students get jobs as this is a good marketing technique. I'm assuming they have a liaison inside their organization that approaches the HR dept of local companies and establishes relationships with them. I think we should have a similar post inside FCC. (And, I'm volunteering for it, if we decide this is indeed something we'd like to do). I can see many advantages for us as we help our campers get jobs.
So that's my hello and goodnight for today. I'll be around more tomorrow!

> My problem is the biggest issue facing the web today - namely the lack of captioning on web video
I've created a free website, nomorecraptions.com to quickly target YouTube videos that only have automatic craptioning and enable anybody to quickly correct these craptions and turn them into something that actually provides accessibility outcomes for users like me (I'm profoundly Deaf).
Whilst PHP has been used in the site at present - I'm more than comfortable looking at converting it for use with javascript frameworks. 
Please get in touch as this is a problem that Google and YouTube have left festering for more than 5 years since they first introduced automatic craptioning and Vimeo only just introduced captioning/subtitle functionality in late 2014! **In fact the videos on this site are a perfect example of the uncaptioned online video resources which are destroying the accessibility of the ‘net.**

Hi Camp Counselors, I have a quick announcement. @Rybar has been a huge help over the past 90 days with the visual design of Free Code Camp, participation in our Live Pair Programming sessions, and helping campers in our chat rooms. 
I just had a candid discussion with Ryan over the phone about the underlying reasons for his desire to resign as a Camp Counselor.
I am happy to say that Ryan has decided to continue as a Camp Counselor!
I will continue to iterate on the Camp Counselor Guide(http://forum.freecodecamp.com/t/camp-counselor-guide/292/1) to remake the expectations of Camp Counselors so that talented - but busy - Camp Counselors like Ryan can continue to help us move Free Code Camp in the right direction without feeling that they are somehow not doing enough.
All the documents we’ve created are living documents. If these documents aren’t realistic, then they are worthless to us. Please help me sand down these documents until they are realistic.
With that, I’d like to retire two concepts we recently introduced that many of you have messaged me about, and that I’ve thought a lot about. The changes are as follows:
1) I’ve closed down the chatroom coverage board. Just hang out here as much as you can.
2) I’ve gotten rid of the “10 hours a week” copy from the Camp Counselor guide. Just use your best judgement and don’t feel obligated to spend time you don’t have here.

RE: chat sign up. It this mandatory? I am happy to help support chat when I can. But committing to a particular time slot doesn't work for me.  #1My sleep schedule is not regular (BTW, I'm in California) - it goes in cycles. Sometimes (like these past few days) I wake up at 3pm and stay awake till about 4 AM. Other times, I keep "standard" hours (you know sleep at night, stay awake during the day).  #2 When I am at my computer, I am studying. This means that I spend 8-10 hours a day studying. I get SUPER distracted with chat (hence my use of the pomodoro timer) and can only pop in during my 5 min breaks. I do spend some time on chat for longer than that, but that is mostly when my brain is in serious need of a break. This need varies from day to day. SO, in short, what I am saying is that I understand the need to have a schedule of coverage AND that I'm willing to be as supportive as I can be BUT I need to be able to be supportive on my onw schedule.

Final note - I have decided to remove all the SQL challenges. There simply isn’t any SQL-related content that’s up to our standards in terms of accessiblity, interactivity and quality. If code campers get stuck on database-related issues later, we can refer them to Stanford’s Database Course or SQLZoo, but having these challenges in the middle of our other challenges creates a drag. A lot of people were simply skipping these.

And everyone who has access to the github account (needed to ban people) - please note that there isn’t currently a way to destroy Gitter rooms (they’re working on it). So I can’t delete joke rooms like my textEditorReligiousWars room and such. So please don’t create unnecessary rooms - better to have a few rooms are active than a bunch of inactive ones without a clear purpose
Please keep these rooms open and if you see a message in there, hop in and see if it’s anything you can help with.

If you have a second, go ahead and open up the “Let’s Pair” and “Help” rooms. Let’s Pair is for people ready to initiate a pair programming session (either Team Viewer or Screen Hero). “Help” is for people who have questions related to our challenges or technologies we use (jQuery, Node.js, etc).
Quick update on the room situation everyone: You can see the existing rooms by going to gitter.im/freecodecamp

Here’s my draft of the first 48 (all browser-based) challenges:
```text
A One-minute Introduction to Free Code Camp (1 min) - FCC
Join the Free Code Camp Chat Room (5 mins) - FCC
Join the Free Code Camp Subreddit (5 mins) - FCC
Build a Personal Webite (60 mins) - Dash
Build a Responsive Blog Theme (60 mins) - Dash
Build a Small Business Website (60 mins) - Dash
Tweak HTML and CSS in CodePen (10 mins) - FCC
Build a CSS Robot (60 mins) - Dash
Tweak HTML and CSS in CodePen (10 mins) - FCC
Meet jQuery (30 mins) - Code School
Traverse the DOM (30 mins) - Code School
Work with the DOM (30 mins) - Code School
Listen for DOM Elements (30 mins) - Code School
Use jQuery for Styling (30 mins) - Code School
Build a MadLibs Game (60 mins) - Dash 
Discover Chrome's DevTools (90 mins) - Code School
Tackle jQuery Exercises (60 mins) - FCC
Customize Bootstrap with Bootswatch (10 mins) - FCC
Inject Life with CSS Transformations (15 mins) - FCC
Learn Computer Graphics from Stanford (120 mins) - Stanford
Learn Loops from Stanford (120 mins) - Stanford
Learn Computer Hardware from Stanford (120 mins) - Stanford
Learn Computer Networking from Stanford (120 mins) - Stanford
Learn Boolean Logic from Stanford (120 mins) - Stanford
Learn Computer Security from Stanford (120 mins) - Stanford
Build a Choose Your Own Adventure Game (90 mins) - Codecademy
Build Rock Paper Scissors (90 mins) - Codecademy
Learn JavaScript For and While Loops (90 mins) - Codecademy
Learn If and Then Statements (90 mins) - Codecademy
Build an Address Book (90 mins) - Codecademy
Build a Cash Register (90 mins) - Codecademy
Get Help The Hacker Way with RSAP (30 mins) - FCC
Learn Regular Expressions (1 hr) - FCC
Start Pair Programming on Coderbyte problems (30 mins) - FCC
Learn Relational Databases from Stanford (60 mins) - Stanford
Pair program on SQL Movie Rating Queries (90 mins) - Stanford
Pair program on SQL Social Network Queries (60 mins) - Stanford
Pair program on SQL Social Network Modification (90 mins) - Stanford
Learn JSON from Stanford (60 mins) - Stanford
Try Source Code Version Control with Git (30 mins) - Code School
Get started with Node.JS works (45 mins) - Code School
Try Node.js Events (45 mins) - Code School
Try Node.js Streams (45 mins) - Code School
See how Node.js Modules work (45 mins) - Code School
Start an Express.js Server (45 mins) - Code School
Use Socket.io (45 mins) - Code School
Use Redis to persist data - Code School
Try MongoDB (30 mins) - FCC
Install Express.js (45 mins) - Code School
Setup Express.js Middleware (45 mins) - Code School
Take advantage of Parameters (45 mins) - Code School
Add the Body Parser (45 mins) - Code School
Configure Routes in Express.js (45 mins) - Code School
```
